column6: List of material topics
column7: IGO Employees on individual contracts and salaries are benchmarked against the market for the employee classification. Collective bargaining agreements cover no IGO employee.\t

column6: Management of material topics
column8: Investment in Research, Collaboration and Innovation
column13: We are committed to continually investing in our organisational capability, innovation and technology to integrate innovation into core business operations. In line with our strategy, we seek better ways to utilise and maximise value from the resources we discover as we work towards our net zero goals. We acknowledge that collaboration with industry experts, peers, governments, and research organisations is crucial to our success in optimising our business value and the success of our industry. These innovation drivers and focus areas are vital in bringing to life the mine of the future.\t
column20: Organizational Capability Investment, Innovation Integration, Net Zero Goals Implementation

column6: Management of material topics
column8: Engaging with the Traditional Owners in exploration activities
column13: As IGOs' HPAs are premised on the conduct of exploration activity by agreement with Traditional Owners, they are an integral component of IGOs' compliance with Aboriginal cultural heritage regimes that operate in Western Australia. IGO's reliance on HPAs for our exploration activities and our commitment to regular meetings and open relationships with Traditional Owners across our operations ensures that IGO will continue to protect cultural heritage now and into the future.\t
column20: Heritage Protection Agreements, Traditional Owner Engagement, Cultural Heritage Preservation

column6: Management of material topics
column13: During FY23, IGO continued to operate under the 2014 Nova Mining Agreement with the Ngadju Native Title Aboriginal Corporation (NNTAC). The Nova Mining Agreement continues to provide significant ongoing benefits to the Ngadju people, including production royalty payments, training, preferential employment and support for Ngadju businesses. In FY23, IGO made production royalty payments totalling $5.1M to the NNTAC. As of 30 June 2023, the Nova Mining Agreement has generated over $24.6M in royalty payments to the NNTAC.
column20: Native Title Agreement Benefits, Indigenous Community Support, Royalty Payments

column6: Management of material topics
column13: Climate change is routinely incorporated into Board discussions, strategy meetings, investment decisions, risk management oversight and monitoring, performance targets and executive remuneration. The Board approves our overall strategy and climate change policy and is ultimately responsible for IGO's management. We have well-established structures and processes to ensure we operate with integrity and conduct business according to our values.\t
column20: Climate Change Governance, Risk Management, Performance Targets

column6: Management of material topics
column13: The Sustainability Committee met five times in FY23, with a Climate Change Performance Review included as an agenda item at each meeting. These performance reviews covered relevant updates on emissions forecasts, deployment of our internal decarbonisation fund, emissions reduction projects underway at Nova, decarbonisation planning at Cosmos, progress on our carbon offset and Scope 3 management strategies.\t
column20: Sustainability Committee, Climate Change Performance Review, Emissions Reduction Initiatives

column6: Direct economic value generated and distributed
Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column7: IGO's strategy is to be a vertically integrated business of products critical to clean energy. Most IGO-supplied raw materials continue to be utilised in the EV market. We are also shifting our business model to further integrate into these supply chains and strengthen our position in the EV battery market.\t

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column8: Internal carbon price and decarbonisation fund
column13: We continue to prioritise financial investment and capital allocation to climate change. The decarbonisation fund allocated $8.3M to support investment in emission reduction projects, research and development, and nature-based solutions.\t
column20: Financial Investment Prioritization, Decarbonization Fund Allocation, Emission Reduction Initiatives

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column13: IGO is undertaking three Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS) trials at the Nova Operation to support long-term net zero goals and help build market confidence in various technologies. We are prioritising research and development that supports IGO's net zero transition strategy, accelerates the mining industry's response to climate change and reduces our dependence on diesel.\t
column20: Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS) Trials, Net Zero Transition Strategy, Technology Development

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column13: IGO supports the need for public disclosure of tailing storage management practices. The Company acknowledges the release of the Global Industry Standard on Tailing Management (GISTM) to ensure no harm to people or the environment through tailing facility design, operation, and closure. We are progressing our review of the analysis of our current TSF practices to the GISTM.\t

column6: Defined benefit plan obligations and other retirement plans
column7: Since the end of the financial year, the Company has announced a fully franked dividend of $454.4M (comprising a final dividend of 44 cents plus a special dividend of 16 cents per fully paid share) to be spent on 28 September 2023.\t

column6: Financial assistance received from government
column7: During FY23, IGO received $581,818 through the Government's Exploration Incentive Scheme and other co-funding programs\t

column6: Ratios of standard entry level wage by gender compared to local minimum wage
column7: IGO complies with local laws and regulations. We ensure our entry-level wages are equal to minimum wages according to local regulations\t

Infrastructure investments and services supported
column7: $1,107M of payments to suppliers for goods and services\t

column6: Infrastructure investments and services supported
column13: All our operations have an approved mine closure plan developed by Western Australian regulations. These Mine Closure Plans (MCPs) are live documents that are continually updated throughout the life of the operation.\t
column20: Mine Closure Plans, Regulatory Compliance, Continual Updates

column6: Significant indirect economic impacts
column7: $471M in payments to employees in salaries and wages, payables to governments in taxes, state royalties and other government payments, returns to shareholders, total costs to Ngadju people and corporate contributions\t

column6: Significant indirect economic impacts
column7: We considered longer-term transition and physical impacts for inclusion in the growth strategy, including additional screening criteria for potential development opportunities.

column6: Proportion of spending on local suppliers
column7: The changing sentiment of conscious consumers choosing responsible brands and sustainably produced products drives companies to consider their supply value chain by ensuring responsible production and transparent oversight of their end-use. In line with our Code of Conduct, we expect all suppliers to maintain the highest standard of ethical behaviour in business dealings. We seek to engage like-minded suppliers and business partners committed to, at minimum, operating safely, lawfully and competently.\t

column6: Operations assessed for risks related to corruption
Communication and training about anti-corruption policies and procedures
column7: All employees receive Corporate Governance training during the company induction, which includes the Anti-Bribery and Corruption Standard.\t

column6: Confirmed incidents of corruption and actions taken
column7: No confirmed incidents of corruption in FY23\t

column6: Legal actions for anti-competitive behavior, anti-trust, and monopoly practices
Approach to tax
column7: We are committed to open and transparent dealings with all our stakeholders at IGO. Tax payment is an essential element of our contribution to the economic development of Australia. During the year, we released our Tax Transparency Report for FY22, which includes details on our approach to tax strategy and governance, effective tax rates and tax contribution summaries.\t

column6: Tax governance, control, and risk management
column7: IGO has processes to regularly review internal controls via internal audit plans, which independent assurance providers and internal resources test. The Board of Directors authorises these plans, and findings are reported by management to the Board or its delegated Committee (Audit and Risk Committee Ã¢ÂÂ ARC). A function of the ARC is to oversee the management of risk. By the ARC's Charter, the ARC oversees and reviews the Company's Tax Risk Management framework and also considers the appropriateness of material tax judgements applied in preparing the Company's financial reports.\t

column6: Tax governance, control, and risk management
column13: IGO's corporate assurance program comprises an internal and external audit, operational reviews and inspections. The external audit is primarily targeted at financial management and is completed by the law and recognised accounting standards. IGO's internal audit process is based on the progressive review of IGO management operating system elements that control high-risk business processes, including internal financial control and ESG management.\t
column20: Corporate Assurance Program, Internal and External Audit, Risk Management

column6: Tax governance, control, and risk management
column13: In FY23, the IGO internal audit program was coordinated by Enumerate. Given the diverse range of matters to be addressed by our non-financial audit, from internet security to geotechnical controls within an underground mine, IGO engages specific subject matter experts as required to complete these internal audits.\t
column20: Internal Audit Coordination, Subject Matter Experts, Non-Financial Audit

column6: Stakeholder engagement and management of concerns related to tax
column7: On 30 August 2022, IGO released its annual Corporate Governance Statement that details IGO's approach to corporate governance. The Board of Directors of IGO have a clear understanding of its responsibility for corporate governance and recognises the importance of its corporate governance framework in establishing accountabilities, guiding and regulating activities, monitoring and managing risks and optimising the Company's performance.\t

column6: Country-by-country reporting
column7: IGO's regular tax obligations from its investment in TLEA will arise from the receipt of expected dividends from cashflows and profits expected to be generated by TLEA's operations. Except for the above, IGO does not have any international-related party dealings. Hence, IGO's Global Effective Tax Rate is similar to its Australian Effective Tax Rate.\t

column6: Materials used by weight or volume
Materials used by weight or volume
column7: Similarly, in FY23, IGO invested in Savanna Burning ACCUs from Arnhem Land Fire Abatement projects. These ACCUs form part of our short and long-term net zero strategies and will be retired to meet targets for hard-to-decrease emissions.\t
column20: Savanna Burning ACCUs, Arnhem Land Fire Abatement Projects, Net Zero Strategies
